div.l: And forth with we he throuȝ thik and then̄
This Millere goth agein no word he seide
But doth his note and with the clerkes pleide
Til that her corn̄ was faire and wel I grounde
And whan the mele is sakked and I bounde
This Iohn goth out and fynt his hors awey
Than gan he to crie harrow and welaway
Oure hors is lost Alein for goddes banes
Step on thi feet com of al atanes
Allas oure wardein has his palfrey lorn̄
This Alein al forgat bothe mele and corn
Al was out of his mynde his husbondrie
What whilk awey is he gan he gan to crie
The wif cam leping inward with a renne
She seid allas your hors goth to the fenne
With wilde mares as fast as he may goo
Vnthank com on his hondes that bond him so
And he that better shuld ha knit the reine
Allas quod Iohn allas for cristes peine
Ley doun thi swerd and I wil myn alswa
I is ful wiȝt god wot as is a Raa
Be goddes herte he shal nat scape vs bathe
Whi ne had thou put the caple in the lathe
Il haill Alein be god thou is a fonne
This seli clerkes han ful fast yronne
Toward the fen bothe Alein and Iohn
And whan the Millere saw that they were gon̄
He half a busshell of her flour hath take
And bade his wif go knede it in a cake
He seid I trowe the clerkes ben aferde
Yit can a Millere make a clerkes berde
Ya for al his art · ye let hem go her wey
Lo where they go · ye let the children pley
They gete him nat so liȝtly be my croune
These seli crerkiscrekiscrerkis rennen vp and doun
With kepe hiere Iossa stand stande war the rere
Go whistele thou and I shal kepe him hiere
But shortli til it was verri niȝt
They coude nat thouȝ they did al her miȝt
Her caple cacche he ran alwey faste
Til in a dich thei cauȝt him ate last
Weri and weet as beste is in the rein
